abstract.p: Joel K Wolfson letter on disputes about Tony Awards suggests awards show be held in real Broadway theater and should be hosted by real theater person rather than 'show-biz groupie' like Rosie O'Donnell; photo (S)

block.p: As the disputes about the Tony Awards heat up, I have some ideas to offer. First, everyone should remember that these awards are about theater. Not about films or television.

The awards show should always be held in a real Broadway theater, the more historic the better. The show's host should always be a true theater person, not some show-biz groupie like Rosie O'Donnell, who, even though a rabid supporter of the ''theater,'' shouldn't be in the same room with real theater people.
As the disputes about the Tony Awards heat up, I have some ideas to offer. First, everyone should remember that these awards are about theater. Not about films or television.

The awards show should always be held in a real Broadway theater, the more historic the better. The show's host should always be a true theater person, not some show-biz groupie like Rosie O'Donnell, who, even though a rabid supporter of the ''theater,'' shouldn't be in the same room with real theater people.

The real television home for this show is on PBS, no commercials, just theater and theater people. Short coherent scenes from the nominated plays deserve a showing. Let the directors and producers select them and air them, as well as the musical numbers, which are always highlighted.
Keep the entire proceedings grown-up, intelligent, fun and indicative of the finest the theater has to offer. Just save us from the likes of Rosie O'Donnell.
JOEL K. WOLFSON San Rafael, Calif.
